name: Getting started with C2000 Device
description:
The objective of this module is to get started with TI Code Composer Studio (CCS)
development environment and run a basic example to toggle LEDs. Specifically,
this module demonstrates how to import a project from a C2000ware, modify/compile the code, 
and run the generated-out file on the target EVM (LaunchPad or controlCARD).

name: Getting started using SysConfig
description:
TI's Code Composer Studio includes a GUI-based tool for
system configuration (SysConfig). It can be used for PinMux
configuration, peripheral setup, and the generation of C-code using
C2000Ware DriverLib API. 
This module goes over how to create a simple SysConfig project to
toggle an LED.

name: Overview of C28x Devices and Accelerators
description:
This introductory module includes an
overview of the basic architecture of the C2000 family of real-time
control microcontrollers.

name: Boot-Mode & Resets
description:
This module describes the boot process and the various types
of resets available on C2000 devices.

name: Interrupts
description:
An interrupt is a response by the processor/CPU to an event that needs attention. 
This module goes over how to setup interrupts and the kinds of interrupts there are
on C2000 devices.

name: Timers
description:
This module describes C28x CPU Timers and the watchdog timer which is a 
safety feature that will reset the device if something goes astray in the system.

name: GPIOs & Crossbars
description:
This module describes General Purpose
Input Output (GPIO) pins, as well as crossbars. Crossbars provide the
ability to route different signals throughout the device.

name: Memory Controller
description:
This module describes the C28x memory controller including the types of Random Access Memory (RAM) 
(Ex. local shared RAM, global shared RAM, message RAM).

name: External Memory Interface (EMIF)
description:
When an application requires more memory than what is available on-chip, the EMIF controller 
can be used to connect to external memory devices. This module goes into details about EMIF
such as the features, configuration, and performance.

name: Flash Memory
description: This module describes C28x flash memory and programming flash memory.

name: Analog to Digital Converter (ADC)
description:
C2000 devices supports multiple analog-to-digital converters (ADCs). This module
describes the different components in the ADC and how to setup the ADC.

name: Comparator Subsystem (CMPSS)
description:
Each Comparator Subsystem (CMPSS) has two comparators within it. This module
describes how the comparators can be used and setup.

name: Digital to Analog Converter (DAC)
description:
The buffered DAC can be used to provide a programmable reference
output voltage. This modules walks though the DAC features and the
DAC block diagram.

name: Programmable Gain Amplifier (PGA)
description:
Programmable Gain Amplifier (PGA) amplifies small input signals to increase the
dynamic range of the downstream ADC and CMPSS modules. This modules showcases 
the benefits of using PGAs and the different parts of the block diagram.

name: Analog Interconnect
description:
The Analog Subsystem Interconnect permits a single pin to route a signal to
multiple analog modules. Thus, enabling a very flexible pin usage, allowing for
smaller device packages.

name: Enhanced Pulse Width Modulation (ePWM)
description:
The C2000 high-performance control peripherals are an integral component for all
digital control systems. This module will cover pulse width modulation (PWM).

name: Enhanced Capture Module (eCAP)
description:
The C2000 enhanced capture module allows time-based logging of external
signal transitions. It is used to accurately time external events by
time stamping transitions on the capture input pin.

name: Enhanced Quadrature Encoder Pulse (eQEP)
description:
The Enhanced Quadrature Encoder Pulse (eQEP) module is essential when
integrating C2000 devices in any application that requires motor control. The
eQEP module enables the C2000 device to interact with linear or rotary
incremental encoders to determine necessary motor information from rotating
machines.

name: Sigma-Delta Filter Module (SDFM)
description:
The C2000 Sigma Delta Filter Module (SDFM) is a four-channel digital filter
designed specifically for current measurement in motor control applications.

name: Communications Overview
description:
C2000 devices contain features that allow several methods of communication and data
exchange between the MCU and other devices. Many of the most commonly used
communications techniques are presented in this module.

name: Fast Serial Interface (FSI)
description:
The FSI module is a highly reliable high-speed serial communication peripheral
capable of operating at dual data rate, providing 100 Mbps transfer using a 50
MHz clock.

name: Serial Communication Interface (SCI)
description:
The SCI is a two-wire asynchronous serial port (also known as a
UART) that supports communications between the processor and other asynchronous
peripherals that use the standard non-return-to-zero (NRZ) format.

name: Inter-Integrated Circuit (I2C)
description:
The I2C provides an interface between devices that connect using an I2C-bus and
are compliant with I2C-bus specification version 2.1.

name: Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI)
description:
The SPI is a high-speed
synchronous serial port that shifts a programmable length serial bit stream
into and out of the device at a programmable bit-transfer rate.

name: Multichannel Buffered Serial Port (MCBSP)
description:
The McBSP
provides a high-speed direct interface to CODECs, analog interface chips
(AICs), and other serially connected A/D and D/A devices.

name: Controller Area Network (CAN)
description:
CAN is a serial communications protocol which efficiently supports distributed
real-time control with a high level of reliability.

name: CAN Flexible Data Rate (CAN FD/MCAN)
description:
CAN FD refers to the protocol while MCAN refers to the physical module
on the device that implements the CAN FD protocol.

name: Local Interconnect Network (LIN)
description:
The LIN standard is based
on the SCI (UART) serial data link format. The communication concept is
single-commander/multiple-responder with a message identification for
multi-cast transmission between any network nodes.

name: Power Management Bus (PMBus)
description:
The PMBus module provides an interface for communicating between the
microcontroller and other devices that are compliant with the System Management
Interface (SMI) specification.

name: Ethernet for Control Automation Technology (EtherCAT)
description:
Ethernet for Control Automation Technology
(EtherCATÂ®) is an Ethernet-based field bus system.

name: Universal Serial Bus (USB)
description:
The USB controller complies
with USB 2.0 Implementers Forum certification standards, and utilizes
full-speed (12 Mbps) operation in device mode and full-/low-speed (12 Mbps/1.5
Mbps) operation in Host mode.

name: Dual Code Security Module (DCSM)
description:
The purpose of code security is to prevent unauthorized access to on-chip 
secure memories such as Flash, RAM, OTP and ROM. In DCSM there are secure 
zones to which securable resources can be assigned.

name: Functional Safety (FuSa)
description:
Functional Safety-Compliant C2000
products can help streamline and speed up the ISO 26262, IEC 61508, and IEC
60730 certification processes with their built-in diagnostics, documentation,
software, and support.

name: Background CRC (BGCRC)
description:
A cyclic redundancy check (CRC) is an error-detecting code that is commonly used
in digital systems. Some C2000 devices feature the background CRC
(BGCRC) module, which computes the CRC value in hardware.

name: Embedded Real-time Analysis and Diagnostic (ERAD)
description:
The ERAD module enhances the debug and system analysis capabilities of
the device. This module facilitates sophisticated non-intrusive
detection and monitoring of the CPU operation in real-time.

name: C2000 Debugging Tips & Tricks
description:
This module describes various topics related to debugging issues on the C2000
family of devices.

name: Embedded Pulse Generator (EPG)
description:
The Embedded Pattern Generator (EPG) module is a customizable pattern and clock
generator that could serve many test and application scenarios that require a
simple pattern generator or a periodic clock generator. The EPG module can also
be used to capture an incoming serial stream of data.

name: Control Law Accelerator (CLA)
description:
The CLA is an independent 32-bit floating-point math hardware accelerator which
executes realtime control algorithms in parallel with the main C28x CPU,
effectively doubling the computational performance.

name: Direct Memory Access (DMA)
description:
The DMA module provides a hardware method of transferring data between
peripherals and/or memory without intervention from the CPU, effectively
freeing up the CPU for other functions.

name: Configurable Logic Block (CLB)
description:
The Configurable Logic Block (CLB) is a peripheral exclusive to C2000 devices
that allows users to incorporate custom logic without the need for an external
logic device such as an FPGA or CLPD.

name: Interprocessor Communications (IPC)
description:
IPC allows communication between two CPU subsystems (ex. CPU1 and CPU2).
This module explains the use and operation of IPC.

name: ADC Lab
description:
Part one consists of sampling a single ADC input channel at a prescribed sampling rate
and storing the conversion result in a circular memory buffer. Part two is to integrate 
the digital-to-analog converter (DAC) into part 1.

name: EPWM/ECAP Lab
description:
Generate a PWM waveform using one of the ePWM modules. The period and
duty cycle of the PWM waveform will be measured by one of the eCAP
modules.

name: EQEP Lab
description:
This lab illustrates a common use-case of the eQEP module- connecting quadrature
signals to the C2000 device and using the eQEP to calculate motor
characteristics.

name: SCI Lab
description:
Utilize the SCI (Serial Communication Interface) by sending and receiving data
between a C2000 device and a computer. The computer will be used to change the
frequency of the blinking LED and then the board will echo this value back to
the computer.

name: CLA Lab
description:
Use the Control Law Accelerator (CLA) to implement a FIR lowpass filter. We will
apply a PWM waveform to the input of our lowpass filter, which will result in a
sinusoidal waveform at the output. The PWM waveform will be generated using one
of the ePWM modules and it will be sampled via the ADC at a given sample rate.

name: DMA Lab
description:
Use the Direct Memory Access (DMA) controller to regularly service the ADC in a
real-time data processing application. The ePWM module will be used to generate
a PWM waveform to simulate a real-time data signal, and the ADC will be setup
to sample the PWM waveform at a chosen sampling rate. Accordingly, the DMA will
be used to store the ADC samples in a ping pong buffer, so groups of samples
can be processed by the CPU in an interrupt service routine (ISR).

name: CLB Lab
description:
Gain familiarity with the Configurable Logic Block (CLB) peripheral and its
submodules through a guided lab example. This lab demonstrations the CLB's
ability to connect to other peripherals, perform logical operations, override
peripheral outputs, and then generate interrupts to the CPU.

name: eCAP Implementation Using CLB Lab
description:
This lab demonstrates the CLB's ability to connect to a signal, accurately time
events, and send data to the CPU. The CLB will measure a high signal, a low
signal, and another high signal before sending the data to the CPU. An external
wave generator or the ePWM module can be set up to supply a signal, if a wave
generator is not available.

name: IPC Lab
description:
Use basic IPC features to send data in both directions between CPU1 and CPU2.
PWM2 will be configured to provide a 50 kHz SOC signal to ADC-A. An
End-of-Conversion ISR on CPU1 will read each result and write it into a data
register in the IPC. An IPC interrupt will then be triggered on CPU2 which
fetches this data and stores it in a circular buffer. The same ISR grabs a data
point from a sine table and loads it into a different IPC register for
transmission to CPU1. This triggers an interrupt on CPU1 to fetch the sine data
and write it into DAC-B.

name: System Integration Lab
description:
This lab builds on all of the different topics covered thus far. As a system
example, the epwm module is setup to output a 50kHz output with a duty cycle
that will vary based on an ADC conversion result. A comparator will also be
used to monitor the ADC conversion results and cause a one-shot trip to drive
the EPWM output low in case the ADC conversion is above a certain threshold.

description: updated or maintained, and are provided "as is".

description: updated or maintained, and are provided "as is".

description: updated or maintained, and are provided "as is".

description: updated or maintained, and are provided "as is".
